ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Audit it. This class reminds me of the Anthropology 100 class I took years ago. I still remember that moment when I asked why points were deducted from my essay that I spent hours on and the prof said, "It was good, but not great. That's all I can tell you." This class reminded my of that moment multiple times. We are supposed to be scientists which means recognizing and eliminating bias. This class seemed to embrace bias as natural. The numbers will most likely prove my point. The TAs mentioned the average grade on the midterm from last year, and this year had a much lower average. This class provides valuable information that I did not receive during my undergrad studies. So I hope Crews continues to provide this class. But there is a dire need to address the issues I've mentioned thus far.
Currently, I'm not sure if I would recommend it for another graduate student. I found a lot of the information interesting, but the course style was clearly undergrady
A survey type course that provides some insights into non-academic careers
I learnt a lot in this class and would definitely recommend it to another student. Different lecture topics are presented by the experts. Industrial perspective is also included.

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: I enjoyed the lectures. I wouldn't say it deepened my knowledge of my discipline. It broadened my knowledge of how biology plays a role in the real world.
